NewEntity.Name: JournalTransaction
NewEntity.Description:
A Transaction records the economic events of the enterprise recorded by accountants to accounts.

Transactions are activities that affect what a business owns, what a business owes and the ownership of the business.   

Transactions are recorded in account(s).     The purpose of the account is to record the information about each business transaction.     

Each part of the transaction will have an effect on a specific ledger account.

Each business transaction involves changes to at least two accounts in a double entry account system.  For any transaction, debits must equal credits.

Each transaction causes at least two changes on the balance sheet.
Transactions must be reported consistently in the same way from period to period.

There are two parties involved in each transaction:   The legal entity recording the transaction (RECORD-KEEPING LEGAL ENTITY) and the other party involved (PARTY).     The other party can also be a legal entity so "Reporting Legal Entity" makes it clear that is the business keeping the books.

Each transaction is first entered into a journal or 'day book' and then posted to a ledger.

Note:
Not all events are transactions.  For example, a change in value of an asset such as land is an example.

Banking Example:
When you deposit a check the bank credits your checking account and debits their cash position.

Note:  Related Transactions are handled by the source document rather than an explicit RELATED TRANSACTION entity.   If the customer feels that this isn't sufficient then a RELATED TRANSACTION entity can be added.

Columns.Name: TransactionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction.

Columns.Name: TransactionTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp of a Transaction.

Columns.Name: TransactionDescription
Columns.Description: The description of a transaction.

Columns.Name: TransactionAmount
Columns.Description: The amount of the transaction.

Columns.Name: JournalTransactionTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Type.

Columns.Name: RecordKeepingLegalEntityId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the book-keeping or reporting Legal Entity.

Columns.Name: TransactionCounterPartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: IntercompanyTransactionIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the transaction is between affiliated companies

Columns.Name: SourceDocumentId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a source document involved in a transaction.

Columns.Name: ExtraordinaryTransactionIndicator
Columns.Description:
A transaction that meets two conditions: 

(1) unusual in nature

(2) infrequent in occurrence

Columns.Name: AccountingProcedureTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Accounting Procedure Type.

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description: The ISO 4217 currency code.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: ProjectId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Project.

Columns.Name: WorkOrderId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Work Order.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

NewEntity.Name: JournalType
NewEntity.Description:
A classification of journal types based on their usage.

Ex:
- General Journal
- A/P Journal
- A/R Journal
- Sales Journal
- Cash Receipts Journal
- Cash Payments Journal
- Purchases Journal

where:

GENERAL JOURNAL records all business transaction not recorded in the special journals below. 

SALES JOURNAL records sales of goods and/or services to customers

PURCHASES JOURNAL records purchases of goods and/or services on credit

CASH RECEIPTS JOURNAL records the receipt of cash

SALES RETURNS AND ALLOWANCES JOURNAL records issue of credit memos giving the buyer credit for the return of merchandise to the seller and a credit for the return.

PURCHASES RETURNS AND ALLOWANCES JOURNAL acknowledges the receipt of a credit memo from the seller authorizing the return of goods and the reduction or elimination of the buyers obligation to the seller.

NewEntity.Name: Ledger
NewEntity.Description:
A ledger is a group of accounts.

It is the complete set of accounts for a business entity.

There is no standard form for a ledger as long as it records debts and credits to each account.

Transactions may be recorded either to a single ledger ('General Ledger') or to subsidiary ledgers and then subsequently recorded to the General Ledger.

It is the book of secondary or final entry after the initial or first entry into a journal, which are then posted to the ledger.

Properties.Description:
A ledger is a group of accounts.

It is the complete set of accounts for a business entity.

There is no standard form for a ledger as long as it records debts and credits to each account.

Transactions may be recorded either to a single ledger ('General Ledger') or to subsidiary ledgers and then subsequently recorded to the General Ledger.

It is the book of secondary or final entry after the initial or first entry into a journal, which are then posted to the ledger.

NewEntity.Name: LedgerAccount
NewEntity.Description:
A Ledger Account is a separate record that is maintained for each category of asset, liability, permanent and temporary capital record.

It is an individual accounting record of increases and decreases in specific asset, liability, and stockholders' equity items.

The purpose of the account is to record the information about each business transaction.

Note:
There can be more than one Chart of Accounts.

Columns.Name: LedgerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Ledger.

Columns.Name: LedgerAccountNumber
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Ledger Account.

Columns.Name: LedgerAccountName
Columns.Description: The name of the ledger account.

Columns.Name: LedgerAccountCreatedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the ledger account was created or established.

Columns.Name: LedgerAccountOpeningBalanceDate
Columns.Description: The date of the ledger account opening balance.

Columns.Name: OpeningBalanceAmount
Columns.Description:
The beginning balance amount of the associated account.

In order for an account to exist it must have a balance that represents the net worth of the account at that time.

Columns.Name: SubaccountIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the account is a subaccount of another account.

Columns.Name: CustomerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

Columns.Name: AccountsPayableLegalEntityId
Columns.Description:
The unique identifier of a Legal Entity.

In this case it is the business, organization or legal entity whose books are being recorded and financial statements presented.

Columns.Name: ProjectId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Project.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: LedgerAccountCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Account Category.

Columns.Name: LedgerAccountTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Account Type.

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description: The ISO 4217 currency code.

Properties.Description:
A Ledger Account is a separate record that is maintained for each category of asset, liability, permanent and temporary capital record.

It is an individual accounting record of increases and decreases in specific asset, liability, and stockholders' equity items.

The purpose of the account is to record the information about each business transaction.

Note:
There can be more than one Chart of Accounts.

NewEntity.Name: LedgerAccountBalanceType
NewEntity.Description:
A categorization of the Ledger Account Balance.

Ex:
Current 

Balance Forward - At month close, all open transactions and the ending balance from the previous month are summarized into a single amount which is then aged as current. This means that all unpaid balances roll forward as a single amount at the beginning of each month with no aging occurring. No transaction detail is therefore kept on file once the month is closed.

Aged Balance Forward - As each month is closed, open transactions are summarized into a monthly total amount, which is then aged as of the last calendar day of that month. (Multiple monthly balances may exist for each customer.) After the month is closed, the transaction detail is not kept on file. This kind of balance type is therefore useful for those customers for whom it is not necessary to keep a transaction by transaction level of detail on file.

ASSETS

LIABILITIES
- A/P
- Notes Payable

REVENUE AND EXPENSES
- Service Revenue
- Rental Revenue
- Commission Revenue
- Rent Expense
- Salaries Expense
- Insurance Expense

NewEntity.Name: LedgerAccountType
NewEntity.Description:
The type of account within the categorization of accounts = ASSETS, LIABILITIES and CAPITAL 

There are various types of accounts that fulfill accounting functions:

TEMPORARY ACCOUNT
Accounts that are zeroes at closing.  For example, revenue and expense accounts are temporary accounts.   At the end of each accounting period, they are closed to Retained Earnings. The change in Retained Earnings during a period is Net Income.

CLEARING ACCOUNT
An account used in the closing process to accumulate temporary items that enter into the calculation of income statement categories.

CONTRA ACCOUNT
An account that accumulates amounts that are in fact subtractions from another account.
For example, Accumulated Depreciation is a deduction from the asset account Plant.

PERMANENT ACCOUNT
An account that is not closed at the end of the accounting period. Accounts whose balances are carried forward to the next accounting period.
Asset, liability and equity accounts are permanent accounts.

NOMINAL ACCOUNT
A revenue or expense account that is closed into retained earnings at the end of the period.

REAL ACCOUNT
A balance sheet account, which is the opposite of a nominal account.

CONTRA REVENUE ACCOUNT
An account that is offset against a revenue account on the income statement.

NewEntity.Name: LedgerType
NewEntity.Description:
Identifies the type of ledger - primarily whether it is a subsidiary ledger or not, which would have a relationship with another ledger.

All general ledger accounts must be reconciled or compared with subsidiary ledgers at the end of each accounting period.

The two most common are A/P Ledgers and A/R Ledgers.

Ex:
The general ledger, sometimes known as the nominal ledger, is the main accounting record of a business which uses double-entry bookkeeping. It will usually include accounts for such items as current assets, fixed assets, liabilities, revenue and expense items, gains and losses.

The general ledger is a summary of all of the transactions that occur in the company. It is built up by posting transactions recorded in the general journal.
There are seven basic categories in which all accounts are grouped:

1. Assets
2. Liability
3. Owner's equity
4. Revenue
5. Expense
6. Gains
7. Losses

The balance sheet and the income statement are both derived from the general ledger. Each account in the general ledger consists of one or more pages. The general ledger is where posting to the accounts occurs. Posting is the process of recording amounts as credits, (right side), and amounts as debits, (left side), in the pages of the general ledger. 

The listing of the account names and the sum of the account balances is called a trial balance. The purpose of the trial balance is, at a preliminary stage of the financial statement preparation process, to ensure the equality of the total debits and credits.

The general ledger should include the date, description and balance or total amount for each account. It is usually divided into at least seven main categories. These categories generally include assets, liabilities, owner's equity, revenue, expenses, gains and losses. The main categories of the general ledger may be further subdivided into sub-ledgers to include additional details of such accounts as cash, accounts receivable, accounts payable, etc.

Because each bookkeeping entry debits one account and credits another account in an equal amount, the double-entry bookkeeping system will ensure that the general ledger will always be in balance; thus maintaining the accounting equation:

NewEntity.Name: NotesToFinancialStatements
NewEntity.Description:
Notes To The Financial Statements are an integral part of the financial statements. Information presented in the various financial statements that comprise the set of financial statements can be cross-referenced to the relevant notes where possible. In the case of IFRS this is mandatory.

Notes provide supplemental information in addition the amounts disclosed in the financial statements. 

They disclose information that doesn't 'fit' into the format of the financial statements. The disclosures required by each of the different accounting frameworks is different.

Typical notes can include:
- Statement of Compliance with Accounting Framework being used
- Accounting Policies
- Critical Account Estimates and Judgments
- Information not present in the financial statements but required by the Accounting Framework
- Commitments
- Leases
- Contingencies
- Pensions

Columns.Description: The period end date for which the set of financial statements is prepared.

Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a financial statement note.

Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Accounting Framework.

Columns.Name: AccountingFrameworkStandardId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Accounting Framework Standard.

Columns.Name: AccountingFrameworkStandardSection
Columns.Description: The section of the Accounting Framework Standard to which the note applies.

NewEntity.Name: RelatedLedger
NewEntity.Description:
The relationship between two or more Ledgers.

In the case of a subledger the Ledger Account Number represents the account to which the related ledger is a subledger for. i.e.. The total of all account balances for the subledger should equal the balance of the Ledger Account Number.

For example:
General Ledger Account 3100 - Accounts Receivable has a balance of $50,000
The Subledger associated with this account is the Accounts Receivable Ledger and it has 250 ledger accounts. The total of all 250 ledger accounts should equal $50,000.

NewEntity.Name: ResponsibilityCenterType
NewEntity.Description:
The type of responsibility center:

Ex:
- Cost center
- Discretionary Cost center (Expenses)
- Revenue center
- Profit Center
- Investment center

where:

COST center is a responsibility center in which a department or organization has responsibility for controlling costs but does not have responsibility for controlling revenues or investment levels.

DISCRETIONARY COST center is a responsibility center in which a department or organization only has responsibility for controlling expenses and staying within a budget.

REVENUE center is a responsibility center in which a department or organization has responsibility for revenues but does not have responsibility for controlling costs or investment levels.

PROFIT center is a responsibility center in which a department or organization has responsibility for revenues and controlling costs but does not have responsibility for investment levels.

INVESTMENT center is a responsibility center in which a department or organization has responsibility for revenues, controlling and the level of investment in the responsibility center.

where:

NewEntity.Name: SecurityIdentificationSource
NewEntity.Description:
A method or source for identifying Financial Products.  

There are currently 65 national numbering agencies issuing more than 20 different local codes.  

Ex:

- ISIN 
- CUSIP  
- SEDOL  
- CEDEL
- VALOREN  
- RIC  
- BLOOMBERG ID
- FTID FTEX
- OUICK
- COMMON CODE
- EUROCLEAR
- SIC
- SICC
- SICOVAM

Cedel   No longer used; replaced by the Common Code on January 1, 1991. 

CIN   CUSIP International Number. Used for non-U.S. and non-Canadian securities. Nine characters. The first character is always a letter, which represents the country of issue. The country codes are as follows: A=Austria, B=Belgium, C=China, D=Germany, E=Spain, F=France, G=Great Britain, H=Switzerland, J=Japan, K=Denmark, L=Luxembourg, M= Middle East, N=Netherlands P= South America, Q=Australia, R=Norway, S=South Africa, T= Italy, U= United States, V =Africa(Other), W= Sweden, X=Europe (Other), Y=Asia. The next five characters are numbers which represent the issuer, followed by two digits representing the security. The final digit is the check digit. 
Common Code   Issued in Luxembourg, replaces CEDEL and Euroclear codes. Nine digits. Final digit is a check digit, computed on a multiplicative system. 

CUSIP   Committee on Uniform Securities Identification Procedures. Standard & Poor's assigns a nine character code to stocks and bonds. The first six characters identify the issuer. The next two characters represent the security that was issued, and the ninth character is a check digit, which is computed using a modulus 10 double add double calculation. For Canadian and U.S. securities, the first character is always a digit. Other countries use an alphabetic first character. See CIN number, above. 

Euroclear   Not used anymore; replaced by the Common Code on January 1, 1991. 

ISIN   International Securities Identification Number. This is a twelve character code developed by the International Standards Organization (ISO) that represents a security. The first two letters always represent the country code, and the ISO standards are used. Basically, these are the same two letters as used in Internet addresses (however GB, not UK, is used for the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland). The next nine characters usually use some other code, such as CUSIP in North America, SEDOL in the United Kingdom, etc. Leading spaces are padded with 0. The final digit is the check digit, also computed with modulus 10 double add double, but it is different from the method used in CUSIP's. 

RIC   Reuter Identification Code. Used on the Reuters Terminal to pull up a particular security. When an equal sign is the last character, that symbol is a master RIC. An RIC that has an equal sign followed by some additional letters means that this string contains the price quoted by some entity. That entity is denoted by those letters following the equal sign. 

SEDOL   Stock Exchange Daily Official List. Securities identification code issued by the London Stock Exchange. Has a built in check digit system. 

SIC   Standard Industrial Code. Tells what line of business a firm is in, does not symbolize a security. 

SICC   Security Identification Code Conference. Used in Japan, usually four digits. Sort of like a ticker in Japan. 

Sicovam SociÉtÉ Interprofessional Pour La Compensation des Valeurs Mobiliers. Used in France. 

SVM   Used in Belgium. 

Valoren Identifier for Swiss securities. No check digit system.

Wertpapier Kenn-nummer  Issued in Germany by the Wertpapier Mitteilungen. Six digits, no check digit. Different ranges of numbers represent different classes of securities. Sometimes called WPK. Note that this number has widespread use in Germany: much more so than the CUSIP in the United States, for instance. 

WKN   See Wertpapier Kenn-Nummer. 

WPK   See Wertpapier Kenn-Nummer. 

Note:
The creation of the international standard ISIN (ISO 6166), essentially an embedded local identifier with a prefixed ISO country code, unified the format of a security identifier and paved the way for the communication of electronic securities messages generated for trading, settlement and registration.    

The underlying problem however is that the international standard (ISIN) alone is not sufficient for the automation requirements of STP.  ISIN is a unique issue identifier, but is not always a unique security identifier.  

ISIN alone is not sufficient for unique identification because one ISIN can be shared among offerings in multiple locations where each offering may have slightly different characteristics that nonetheless have a significant impact.  

EPIC 
Commonly used on the UK stock market.
 
QUICK
A numbering system used in Japan

Note:
The creation of the international standard ISIN (ISO 6166), essentially an embedded local identifier with a prefixed ISO country code, unified the format of a security identifier and paved the way for the communication of electronic securities messages generated for trading, settlement and registration.    

The underlying problem however is that the international standard (ISIN) alone is not sufficient for the automation requirements of STP.  ISIN is a unique issue identifier, but is not always a unique security identifier.  

ISIN alone is not sufficient for unique identification because one ISIN can be shared among offerings in multiple locations where each offering may have slightly different characteristics that nonetheless have a significant impact.

RIC   Reuter Identification Code. Used on the Reuters Terminal to pull up a particular security. When an equal sign is the last character, that symbol is a master RIC. An RIC that has an equal sign followed by some additional letters means that this string contains the price quoted by some entity. That entity is denoted by those letters following the equal sign. 

SEDOL   Stock Exchange Daily Official List. Securities identification code issued by the London Stock Exchange. Has a built in check digit system. 

SIC   Standard Industrial Code. Tells what line of business a firm is in, does not symbolize a security. 

SICC   Security Identification Code Conference. Used in Japan, usually four digits. Sort of like a ticker in Japan. 

Sicovam SociÉtÉ Interprofessional Pour La Compensation des Valeurs Mobiliers. Used in France. 

SVM   Used in Belgium. 

Valoren Identifier for Swiss securities. No check digit system.

Wertpapier Kenn-nummer  Issued in Germany by the Wertpapier Mitteilungen. Six digits, no check digit. Different ranges of numbers represent different classes of securities. Sometimes called WPK. Note that this number has widespread use in Germany: much more so than the CUSIP in the United States, for instance. 

WKN   See Wertpapier Kenn-Nummer. 

WPK   See Wertpapier Kenn-Nummer. 

Note:
The creation of the international standard ISIN (ISO 6166), essentially an embedded local identifier with a prefixed ISO country code, unified the format of a security identifier and paved the way for the communication of electronic securities messages generated for trading, settlement and registration.    

The underlying problem however is that the international standard (ISIN) alone is not sufficient for the automation requirements of STP.  ISIN is a unique issue identifier, but is not always a unique security identifier.  

ISIN alone is not sufficient for unique identification because one ISIN can be shared among offerings in multiple locations where each offering may have slightly different characteristics that nonetheless have a significant impact.  

EPIC 
Commonly used on the UK stock market.
 
QUICK
A numbering system used in Japan

Note:
The creation of the international standard ISIN (ISO 6166), essentially an embedded local identifier with a prefixed ISO country code, unified the format of a security identifier and paved the way for the communication of electronic securities messages generated for trading, settlement and registration.    

The underlying problem however is that the international standard (ISIN) alone is not sufficient for the automation requirements of STP.  ISIN is a unique issue identifier, but is not always a unique security identifier.  

ISIN alone is not sufficient for unique identification because one ISIN can be shared among offerings in multiple locations where each offering may have slightly different characteristics that nonetheless have a significant impact.

NewEntity.Name: StatementOfCashFlows
NewEntity.Description:
The Statement of Cash Flow Statement reports inflows and outflows as cash - focusing upon profitability.

Cash flow from operating activities represents cash generated internally.   Investing and financing activities represents cash from external sources.

The Statement of Cash Flows is a reordering of information from the balance sheet.   The balance sheet shows account balances at the end of an accounting period, whereas the statement of cash flows shows 'changes' in the same account balances between accounting periods. 

It is a statement of 'flows' because it shows changes over time rather than the absolute dollar amount of the accounts at a point in time as with the balance sheet.

The Statement of Cash Flows is prepared by calculating the changes in all of the balance sheet accounts and then listing the accounts as inflows/outflows by operating, financing and investing activities.

The inflows less the outflows balance to and explain the change in the cash position.

The Statement of Cash Flows helps management estimate future cash requirements.

The Statement of Cash Flows has 3 sections:   

(1)  Cash Flow From Operating Activities
(2)  Cash Flow From Investing Activities
(3)  Cash Flow From Financing Activities

Columns.Name: LegalEntityId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Legal Entity.

Columns.Name: FinancialStatementId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Financial Statement.

Columns.Name: PeriodStartDate
Columns.Description: The period start date for which the financial statement is prepared.

Columns.Name: PeriodEndDate
Columns.Description: The period end date for which the financial statement is prepared.

Columns.Name: ReceiptsFromCustomers
Columns.Description: Cash received from customers for services and or goods purchased.

Columns.Name: PaymentsToSuppliersAndEmployees
Columns.Description: Cash paid out to suppliers and employees for various obligations.

Columns.Name: CashGeneratedFromOperations
Columns.Description: Cash generated from operations. Calculated based on above values.

Columns.Name: InterestPaid
Columns.Description: Cash paid to support interest-related fees and charges.

Columns.Name: IncomeTaxesPaid
Columns.Description: Cash paid for income taxes.

Columns.Name: NetCashGeneratedByOperatingActivities
Columns.Description: The net amount of cash flow from operations.

Columns.Name: PaymentsToAcquireFinancialAssets
Columns.Description: Cash paid for the purchase of financial assets.

Columns.Name: ProceedsOnSaleOfFinancialAssets
Columns.Description: Cash received for the sale of financial assets.

Columns.Name: InterestReceived
Columns.Description: The amount of interest received from interest bearing investments.

Columns.Name: RoyaltiesAndOtherInvestmentIncomeReceived
Columns.Description: Cash received from investment income.

Columns.Name: DividendsReceived
Columns.Description: The amount of dividends received.

Columns.Name: PaymentsForPropertyPlantAndEquipment
Columns.Description: Cash paid out for property, plant and equipment.

Columns.Name: ProceedsFromDisposalOfPropertyPlantEquipmentAmount
Columns.Description: Cash received from the sale of property, plant and equipment.

Columns.Name: NetCashGeneratedByInvestingActivities
Columns.Description: Net positive/negative cash flow from investment activities.

Columns.Name: ProceedsFromIssueOfEquityInstruments
Columns.Description: Cash received for the issue of equity instruments.

Columns.Name: ProceedsFromIssueOfConvertibleNotes
Columns.Description: Cash received from issue of convertible notes.

Columns.Name: PaymentForRepurchaseOfShares
Columns.Description: Cash paid for the repurchase of stock/treasury stock.

Columns.Name: ProceedsFromBorrowings
Columns.Description: Cash received through undertaking of borrowing / loans.

Columns.Name: RepaymentOfBorrowings
Columns.Description: Cash paid for the repayment of loans.

Columns.Name: DividendsPaidOnRedeemablePreferenceShares
Columns.Description: The amount of dividends paid on redeemable preference shares during the period.

Columns.Name: DividendsPaidToOwnersOfTheCompany
Columns.Description: Cash paid for dividends.

Columns.Name: NetCashUsedInFinancingActivities
Columns.Description: The net positive/negative cash flow from financing activities.

Columns.Name: NetIncreaseInCashAndCashEquivalents
Columns.Description: The net increase/decrease in cash for the period.

Columns.Name: CashAndCashEquivalentsAtTheBeginningOfPeriod
Columns.Description: The amount of cash at the beginning of period.

Columns.Name: CashAndCashEquivalentsAtTheEndOfPeriod
Columns.Description: The amount of cash at the end of period.

Columns.Name: CashFlowStatementPreparationMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Cash Flow Preparation Method.

Properties.Description:
The Statement of Cash Flow Statement reports inflows and outflows as cash - focusing upon profitability.

Cash flow from operating activities represents cash generated internally.   Investing and financing activities represents cash from external sources.

The Statement of Cash Flows is a reordering of information from the balance sheet.   The balance sheet shows account balances at the end of an accounting period, whereas the statement of cash flows shows 'changes' in the same account balances between accounting periods. 

It is a statement of 'flows' because it shows changes over time rather than the absolute dollar amount of the accounts at a point in time as with the balance sheet.

The Statement of Cash Flows is prepared by calculating the changes in all of the balance sheet accounts and then listing the accounts as inflows/outflows by operating, financing and investing activities.

The inflows less the outflows balance to and explain the change in the cash position.

The Statement of Cash Flows helps management estimate future cash requirements.

The Statement of Cash Flows has 3 sections:   

(1)  Cash Flow From Operating Activities
(2)  Cash Flow From Investing Activities
(3)  Cash Flow From Financing Activities

NewEntity.Name: StatementOfComprehensiveIncome
NewEntity.Description:
The Statement of Comprehensive Income details the amount of income and how it was earned. 

It is a summary of the revenue, expenses and net income/net loss of the legal entity for a specific period where:

REVENUE = The increase in capital as a result of the sale of goods or services provided by the business.   The revenue is equal to the cash, accounts receivable and other assets gained in compensation for goods sold or services rendered.

EXPENSES = The decrease in capital that is the result of the business' revenue-producing operations.   The expenses amount is equal to the value of the goods and services used up or consumed in obtaining the revenue.

NET INCOME = The increase in capital that is the result from profitable operation of the business during the period.   It is the excess of revenues over expenses for the accounting period.

NET LOSS = The decrease in capital resulting from the operations of the business.   It is the excess of expenses over revenue for the operating period.

It is a record of its earnings or losses for a given period. It shows all of the money a company earned (revenues) and all of the money a company spent (expenses) during this period. 

It documents the changes in the balance sheet retained earnings account from one period to the next (see Stockholders Equity Retained Earnings).

It also accounts for the effects of some basic accounting principles such as depreciation.

It is for a specific period of time, where the balance sheet is at a specific instance of time.

Properties.Description:
The Statement of Comprehensive Income details the amount of income and how it was earned. 

It is a summary of the revenue, expenses and net income/net loss of the legal entity for a specific period where:

REVENUE = The increase in capital as a result of the sale of goods or services provided by the business.   The revenue is equal to the cash, accounts receivable and other assets gained in compensation for goods sold or services rendered.

EXPENSES = The decrease in capital that is the result of the business' revenue-producing operations.   The expenses amount is equal to the value of the goods and services used up or consumed in obtaining the revenue.

NET INCOME = The increase in capital that is the result from profitable operation of the business during the period.   It is the excess of revenues over expenses for the accounting period.

NET LOSS = The decrease in capital resulting from the operations of the business.   It is the excess of expenses over revenue for the operating period.

It is a record of its earnings or losses for a given period. It shows all of the money a company earned (revenues) and all of the money a company spent (expenses) during this period. 

It documents the changes in the balance sheet retained earnings account from one period to the next (see Stockholders Equity Retained Earnings).

It also accounts for the effects of some basic accounting principles such as depreciation.

It is for a specific period of time, where the balance sheet is at a specific instance of time.

NewEntity.Name: StatementOfFinancialPosition
NewEntity.Description:
The Statement of Financial Position is a 'snapshot' of the legal entity's financial position as of a single time.

The Statement of Financial Position is a financial statement that reports the assets, liabilities and equity of a legal entity as of a date or point in time.    Assets are listed on the left and liabilities and equity on the right. 

Since the assets and liabilities position of the entity may change every day there must be a reported date to identify the exact point in time in which the information is valid.

The Statement of Financial Position is considered to be the financial position of the legal entity as of the date on the statement.

The basic equation that is the foundation of the balance sheet is:

Assets = Liabilities + Equity

Each transaction causes at least two changes on the balance sheet.

The following is the representative 'template' of a simple Statement of Financial Position that can easily be customized for the target entity.

Columns.Name: LegalEntityId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Legal Entity.

Columns.Name: FinancialStatementId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Financial Statement.

Columns.Name: PeriodStartDate
Columns.Description: The period start date for which the financial statement is prepared.

Columns.Name: PeriodEndDate
Columns.Description: The period end date for which the financial statement is prepared.

Columns.Name: InvestmentProperty
Columns.Description: Property as a fixed asset refers to property not used in the business and is acquired for investment purposes only.

Columns.Name: Goodwill
Columns.Description: The value of goodwill held.

Columns.Name: Copyrights
Columns.Description: The value of copyrights held.

Columns.Name: Patents
Columns.Description: The value of patents held.

Columns.Name: Property
Columns.Description:
Property, Plant And Equipment represent a company's fixed assets that are not consumed in the annual business operations and provide economic benefits for more than one year.

They are considered tangible because they have physical substance.

Land as a fixed asset refers to property used in the business.

Columns.Name: BuildingsAndLeaseholdImprovements
Columns.Description:
Property, Plant And Equipment represent a company's fixed assets that are not consumed in the annual business operations and provide economic benefits for more than one year.

They are considered tangible because they have physical substance.

Buildings include buildings and structures owned by the company.   Leasehold improvements are additions or improvements made to leased structures.    They are amortized by the lessee over the economic life of the improvement or the life of the lease whichever is shorter.

Columns.Name: Equipment
Columns.Description:
Property, Plant And Equipment represent a company's fixed assets that are not consumed in the annual business operations and provide economic benefits for more than one year.

They are considered tangible because they have physical substance.

Equipment represents the original cost including delivery and installation of the machinery and equipment used in business operations less any accumulated depreciation. 

Under IFRS, assets and their associated accumulated depreciation are aggregated to provide a better reflection of the current value of the asset to the organization.

Columns.Name: OtherAssets
Columns.Description: Other assets can include any number of noncurrent items such as property for sale, start-up costs, advance payments etc.

Columns.Name: NoncurrentAssetsTotal
Columns.Description: The total amount of non-current assets recorded.

Columns.Name: NotesReceivable
Columns.Description:
Written promises to receive stated sums of money at future dates, classified as current (if due within 12 months) or non-current (if due after 12 months) of the balance sheet date.

Read more: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/notes-receivable.html#ixzz17ie7v8jz

Columns.Name: Inventory
Columns.Description: Inventories are items held for sale or used in the manufacture of products that will be sold.

Columns.Name: MarketableSecurities
Columns.Description:
Cash substitutes that is temporarily invested to earn a return.   These are short-term maturity instruments of less than one year maturity.

They should be relatively 'riskless' securities or investments.

Columns.Name: PrepaidExpenses
Columns.Description: Expenses such as insurance, rent, property taxes that are paid in advance.

Columns.Name: AccountsReceivablesLessAllowanceForDoubtfulAccounts
Columns.Description:
Accounts receivables are customer balances on outstanding credit sales that are reported at their net realizable value - minus any allowance for doubtful accounts.

Doubtful accounts are those the management judges to be uncollectible during the account period.

Columns.Name: CashAndBank
Columns.Description: Cash in any form - such as waiting to be deposited, in bank accounts, checking accounts.

Columns.Name: CurrentAssetsTotal
Columns.Description: The total amount of current assets.

Columns.Name: AssetsTotal
Columns.Description: The total of all assets - current + noncurrent.

Columns.Name: CommonStockIssued
Columns.Description: Common stockholders have voting rights but do not receive a fixed return.    Dividends are declared by the company at the discretion of the board of directors.

Columns.Name: RetainedEarnings
Columns.Description:
Retained earnings is the sum of the company has earned since its inception minus any payments made to shareholders in the form of cash or stock dividends.

Retained earnings are funds a company has elected to reinvest in the operations of the business rather than pay out to stockholders in dividends.   

It is a measure of all undistributed earnings.

Columns.Name: EquityTotal
Columns.Description: The total amount of stockholders equity.

Columns.Name: MortgagesPayable
Columns.Description: The mortgages held by the company.

Columns.Name: Bonds
Columns.Description: Bonds that may be sold to the investing public.

Columns.Name: OtherLongTermDebt
Columns.Description: Deferred long term debt.

Columns.Name: DeferredTaxLiabilities
Columns.Description: Deferred federal taxes.

Columns.Name: ContingentLiabilities
Columns.Description:
Potential liabilities arising from past events - that a potential liability exists in the future.

Ex:
- Tax assessments
- Product warranties
- Pending lawsuits
- Litigation

Columns.Name: NoncurrentLiabilitiesTotal
Columns.Description: The total amount of noncurrent liabilities.

Columns.Name: CurrentMaturitiesOfLongTermDebt
Columns.Description: The amount that will be repaid during the current year on long-term debt outstanding such as bonds, mortgages etc.

Columns.Name: NotesPayable
Columns.Description: Notes payable are short-term obligations in the form of promissory notes to suppliers or similar legal entities.

Columns.Name: AccountsPayable
Columns.Description: AP are short-term obligations due from credit extended by suppliers etc. for the purchase of goods and services.

Columns.Name: CurrentTaxLiabilities
Columns.Description: The total amount of current liabilities assigned to Taxes.

Columns.Name: CurrentLiabilitiesTotal
Columns.Description: The total amount of current liabilities.

Columns.Name: LiabilitiesTotal
Columns.Description: The total amount of liabilities.

Columns.Name: EquityAndLiabilitiesTotal
Columns.Description: The total of all liabilities plus stockholders equity.

Properties.Description:
The Statement of Financial Position is a 'snapshot' of the legal entity's financial position as of a single time.

The Statement of Financial Position is a financial statement that reports the assets, liabilities and equity of a legal entity as of a date or point in time.    Assets are listed on the left and liabilities and equity on the right. 

Since the assets and liabilities position of the entity may change every day there must be a reported date to identify the exact point in time in which the information is valid.

The Statement of Financial Position is considered to be the financial position of the legal entity as of the date on the statement.

The basic equation that is the foundation of the balance sheet is:

Assets = Liabilities + Equity

Each transaction causes at least two changes on the balance sheet.

The following is the representative 'template' of a simple Statement of Financial Position that can easily be customized for the target entity.

NewEntity.Name: TaxBasis
NewEntity.Description:
The basis by which revenues are considered:

Ex:
- Cash, revenues are considered earned at the time they are received in cash and expenses are considered to be incurred at the time cash is disbursed in their payment.

- Accrual, revenues are credited to the period in which they are earned regardless of when payment is received.

Columns.Name: TaxBasisId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Tax Basis.

Columns.Name: TaxBasisName
Columns.Description: The name of a Tax Basis.

Columns.Name: TaxBasisDescription
Columns.Description: The description of a Tax Basis.

NewEntity.Name: WriteOffMethod
NewEntity.Description:
There are three methods that are used to recognize customer obligations that are uncollectible:

1. - Direct Write-off Method
2 -  Net Sales Method
3 -  Aging of Accounts Receivable Method
